abstract.p: Letter from Scott Amrhein (Center for Continuing Care, Greater New York Hospital Association) says Jonathan Kozol's Aug 22 Op-Ed article on his father's Alzheimer's underscores need to reform long-term care financing in this country

block.p: Jonathan Kozol's poignant account of his father's experience with Alzheimer's disease (Op-Ed, Aug. 22) underscores the need to reform long-term care financing in our country.

New York State offers people the opportunity -- through the Partnership for Long Term Care program -- to buy a qualified long-term care insurance plan that permits them, once the plan's benefits are exhausted, to qualify for long-term care coverage under Medicaid while protecting their savings and other assets.
Jonathan Kozol's poignant account of his father's experience with Alzheimer's disease (Op-Ed, Aug. 22) underscores the need to reform long-term care financing in our country.

New York State offers people the opportunity -- through the Partnership for Long Term Care program -- to buy a qualified long-term care insurance plan that permits them, once the plan's benefits are exhausted, to qualify for long-term care coverage under Medicaid while protecting their savings and other assets.

Many New Yorkers do not take advantage of this program based on a lack of awareness or concern that the program, offered only in New York and three other states, may not be available in the state in which they plan to retire. It is vital that New York's program be replicated as a national program.
The writer is executive director, Center for Continuing Care, Greater New York Hospital Association.
